Here is a simplified version of the passage, written for a B2 level learner:

Advertising is not as effective as it used to be. This is not just because of the recession, but because advertising has not kept up with the way the economy has changed. Advertisers often focus on big groups of people, but as more brands and media options have become available, target audiences have become smaller. This means that even big brands often don't reach the people who will actually buy their products.

Think about your own shopping habits. You probably buy a few dozen items from a supermarket, but most of them are not advertised brands. You might buy a handful of advertised brands, but not many more. Over a year, you might buy a few hundred different brands, but that's out of the 15,000 or so products available.

There are 32,500 branded goods and services advertised, but most people don't buy more than 400 of them a year. In fact, the average person buys only about 4% of the advertised brands. This means that 96% of advertising is wasted, because the people who see the ads are not interested in the products.

When you watch TV, you might see a few ads for brands you buy or might buy. But most people don't buy most of the advertised brands. The truth is that nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised.

Advertising is not a perfect way to reach people. It's a cheap way to communicate with a large group of people, but it's not precise. Advertisers can't know exactly who will respond to their ads. Even direct mail shots, which are more targeted, don't always get a 100% response.

The best way to make advertising more effective is to target it more precisely. Advertisers need to focus on the people who will actually buy their products, rather than trying to reach a large group of people.<|eot_id|>

**Abyss**

Before making Titanic, director James Cameron made this thrilling movie about a team trying to rescue a submarine trapped under water. The story is a bit predictable and is similar to other B-movie plots.

**The Thin Red Line**

This war movie is based on a novel by James Jones. It's about a soldier's experiences during the battle of Guadalcanal. The director, Andrew Marton, made a more traditional war movie compared to Terrence Malick's version. Marton's film is more faithful to the book and focuses on the soldier's relationships with his sergeant and wife. Malick's film is more complex and poetic, but Marton's version has its own strengths, such as a powerful flashback sequence.

**On Guard**

This swashbuckling adventure is loosely based on a novel by Paul Feval. It's a fun and entertaining movie with a great villain and exciting action scenes. The actors, including Vincent Perez and Daniel Auteuil, do a good job. The film's costume design and production values are impressive, making it feel like a classic adventure movie.

**Character**

This movie is set in turn-of-the-century Rotterdam and is a dark and serious tale about a brutal bailiff and his son. The production design and costumes are very detailed, but the film's focus on these elements makes it feel like a museum piece. The story is about the bailiff's cruel treatment of his tenants, but it's not fully explored.

**The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**

This digitally re-mastered video release shows off director Leone's craftsmanship. The sound effects are impressive, and the music by Morricone is fantastic. The story is cruel and violent, and the characters are all morally ambiguous. It's a classic Western movie that's worth watching.

**The Longest Day**

This three-hour war epic has an impressive cast and crew, but it feels overlong and dragged out. The early scenes are slow, and the movie is best seen on the big screen. It's an impressive feat of filmmaking, but it's not as effective on video.

Print advertising is still much more profitable than online advertising. However, maintaining both print and digital editions is expensive and complex.

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

**Photographing People**

Taking pictures of people is the most interesting thing to do. When someone is in the picture, it's usually more interesting than a picture without a person. However, people are also the most difficult to take good pictures of. The photographer needs to think about the person's actions, gestures, and expressions. The camera can also make them feel awkward.

**Tips for Taking Good Pictures of People**

A. **Group Shots**
When taking a group picture, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so everyone's faces are visible.

B. **Posing**
People often don't act naturally in front of a camera. They might stiffen up and look uncomfortable. To relax them, suggest they find a comfortable position. You can also ask them to put their hands in their pockets or fold their arms.

C. **Approach**
Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when it's clear you are. This can make people feel uneasy or even angry. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, and they might even be flattered. However, they might become self-conscious and need some direction.

D. **Eye Contact**
A picture becomes more interesting if the person looks directly at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens, but not necessarily smile. This will create a natural effect.

E. **Candid Shots**
An alternative to direct eye contact is to have the person focus on something within the picture area. This can make the viewer feel like they're observing the person unnoticed.

F. **Expressions and Gestures**
Expressions and gestures can tell us more about the person in the picture than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like smiling, laughing, or frowning.

G. **Background**
The background or environment can add interest and information to the picture. Try to exclude unnecessary details or blur them to make the subject stand out.

H. **Interaction**
When taking pictures of people interacting with each other, look for contact between them, such as eye contact or physical touch.

I. **People and Places**
When taking pictures of people in a new place, try to show them against a relevant background. Use a standard or wide-angle lens and move back to get the whole scene in the frame.

J. **To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's for a formal occasion, a posed picture might be suitable. However, for candid shots, it's better to capture the moment naturally.

Note: I've kept the main ideas and tips from the original text, but simplified the language and sentence structure to make it easier for a B2 level learner to understand.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the text for a B2 learner:

Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success

The way we work is changing. We're no longer judged just on how smart we are or how well we've been trained. We're also judged on how well we work with others and how we handle ourselves. This is becoming more important when choosing who to hire or promote.

In the past, we were told that being good at school was the most important thing. But now, it's not just about being clever. It's about having good social skills and personal qualities like being able to work well with others, being adaptable, and being able to persuade people.

Emotional intelligence is the ability to understand and manage our own and others' feelings. It's made up of five key elements: self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills.

Some people think that emotional intelligence means being nice all the time. But it's not just about being nice. It's about knowing when to be blunt and honest, and when to be kind and understanding. It's about managing our feelings so that we can work well with others.

More and more companies are realizing that emotional intelligence is important. They're teaching their employees how to be more emotionally intelligent. This is especially important in jobs that require teamwork and working with customers.

The good news is that emotional intelligence can be developed and improved over time. We can learn to be more emotionally intelligent as we grow and learn from our experiences. This is important because the job market is changing, and we need to be adaptable and able to work well with others to succeed.

Emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, but it's an important part of being successful in the workplace.<|eot_id|>

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a B2 level learner:

Acupuncture is an ancient Chinese treatment that has been used for over 2,000 years. It's based on traditional Chinese medicine, which believes that health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but its role in relieving pain has received the most attention from Western doctors.

In traditional Chinese medicine, there is a flow of energy called Qi that runs through the body along specific paths called meridians. When the flow of Qi is blocked or imbalanced, it can cause weakness or illness. An acupuncturist tries to find where the imbalance is and uses fine needles to restore the flow of Qi.

There are over 300 points on the body where the needles are inserted, and people often feel a gentle tingling sensation when the needle is manipulated. This shows that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian.

Western doctors have accepted that acupuncture can work for pain relief, even if they don't believe in the principles of traditional Chinese medicine. They think it might work because it stimulates nerves that block pain signals to the brain or releases natural pain-relieving substances.

Acupuncture is used to treat many types of pain, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. Some people use it as a last resort for chronic pain, and it can be especially helpful for people who don't respond well to other treatments.

Acupuncture has also been used during surgery, especially in China, where it has been used for over 50 years. It's claimed to eliminate pain without the side effects of conventional anesthesia. However, it's not suitable for everyone, and people should choose an acupuncturist carefully.

In traditional acupuncture, the practitioner views the patient holistically, taking into account not just the symptoms but also the patient's overall health, lifestyle, and environment. This approach can be different from Western medicine, which often focuses on specific symptoms.

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others reject traditional Chinese theory and focus on scientific explanations. However, many traditional acupuncturists believe that their approach can lead to deeper and longer-lasting changes in the body.

Remember to always take care when choosing an acupuncturist and to consult with a medical doctor if necessary.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is a growing field that studies a person's character and personality based on their handwriting. In some countries, employers use graphology to assess job applicants. Researchers claim that handwriting can reveal information about a person's health, such as heart disease and cancer, as well as their emotional state and psychological characteristics.

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist, believes that handwriting can be a powerful tool in assessing a person's suitability for a job or predicting their behavior. She says that handwriting can indicate a person's social class, intelligence, and mental abilities. Graphology can also be used to identify potential criminals, as they often have unusual or poorly shaped handwriting.

According to Marne, graphology can predict whether someone is honest, manipulative, or reliable. It can also detect signs of emotional distress, such as stress, anxiety, or depression. In addition, handwriting can reveal a person's creativity, confidence, and artistic ability.

However, not all experts agree with Marne's claims. Some doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the value of graphology, saying that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught. They argue that there is little scientific evidence to support the claims made by graphologists.

Despite the controversy, Marne believes that graphology has the potential to be a valuable tool in understanding human behavior and predicting future behavior. She suggests that more research is needed to establish the scientific validity of graphology.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

Chewing gum is a popular habit in the United States. Americans chew around 12 million sticks of gum every day. But did you know that chewing gum has a long history? Let's explore how it became a big business.

In ancient Greece, people chewed a resin from the mastic tree to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. Later, American colonists started chewing a resin from spruce trees. This was the first commercial chewing gum in the United States.

In the 1860s, a new type of gum was discovered in Central America. It was made from the sap of the sapodilla tree. This gum was smoother and more enjoyable to chew than earlier versions. The chewing gum industry was born.

However, it's difficult to grow sapodilla trees commercially. Today, only a few people, called chicleros, collect the sap. They face many challenges, including poisonous snakes, insects, and a special type of fly that lays its eggs in their ears and nose.

Despite these dangers, chicleros continue to collect sap to make gum. But the demand for gum has increased, and manufacturers are now using synthetic materials to reduce costs. Gum producers are also finding new ways to market their products, claiming that it can help with relaxation, energy, and even reduce tooth decay.

The body's natural defense against tooth decay is saliva, which neutralizes acid and supplies minerals like calcium and fluoride. Chewing gum can increase saliva flow, which can help with oral health. Researchers are also experimenting with new textures and flavors, using glycerine and other vegetable oils.

Interestingly, the United States devotes over 137 square kilometers to growing the mint used in two of the most popular chewing gums in the world.

Here is the simplified text:

**Conquering the Seven Summits**

I, Doug Scott, share my experiences climbing the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. I started my journey late in life, and here's how I did it.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**

I climbed Mt. Everest with my partner, Dougal Haston. We spent two days on the summit ridge, and I realized that I couldn't have done it with a better partner. We had to work together to reach the top.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**

Mt. McKinley is considered the most treacherous mountain in the world. Dougal and I spent four days carrying our equipment and food to the base. We decided to climb "alpine style," with our gear on our backs. We were exhausted by the third day, but we finally reached the summit.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**

Paul Braithwaite and I flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya, but we ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. We got lost in the jungle, but found a trail of rubbish that led us to a rock pool. We took a different route to the summit, which was surreal.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**

I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. We met a guide named Phil, who suggested we take a new route. We walked across the glacier and joined the many people climbing the standard route. The wind was strong, but we reached the summit.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**

I joined a team to climb Vinson Massif, which was a matter of guiding people to finance the trip. We traveled to the South Pole and climbed the mountain. The weather was bad, but we reached the summit in 8 hours.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**

Our team assembled in St. Petersburg and climbed Elbrus. We took a cableway to 3,900m and walked to the refuge at 4,200m. The wind was strong, but we reached the summit.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**

We climbed Carstensz Pyramid to spend time with the aboriginal Dani people. We warned about potential danger, but we climbed the mountain and reached the summit. I was given a standing ovation for completing my seventh summit.

I hope this simplified text is suitable for a B2 learner.<|eot_id|>

We had been living in our valley for 16 months when we realized that the surrounding hills could pose a threat to our survival. It was a year when the storms came early, even before November. We had felt safe and sheltered in our valley, protected by the hills. But then snow started falling. It was deep, up to 15 centimeters, and blocked our lane and made the path slippery. The snow was deeper on the nearby hills, and the wind was strong. In our valley, we only felt strong gusts of wind, but we knew we should be worried. The river, the Ryburn, was a bigger concern. It usually flowed gently, but if the snow had not been controlled by dams many years ago, it could have been a disaster. The snow started to melt, and we watched as the clouds grew thicker and darker. The river became fuller and wilder every day. We knew the dam was approaching its limit, and then it happened - the dam overflowed for the first time in years. The water rushed down the stream, making it deeper and wilder than ever before. We were worried, but luckily the dam held, and the water subsided. In the past, the river had flooded nearby villages, but now the dam controls its flow, and we can enjoy the power of the river without fear. Thanks to the dam, we can feel safe in our valley.

Chocolate is a popular treat that has its roots in South America. Today, it's a big business worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter, which is a lot! Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. The history of chocolate goes back over 3,000 years to the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations. They grew a special tree called the cacao tree, which produces a fruit with 20-40 seeds. When these seeds are dried, they become cacao beans, which can be used to make chocolate.

In the past, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which was bitter and flavored with spices. The Spanish liked it better when it was mixed with cinnamon and sugar. For a long time, only the rich could afford chocolate. In the 17th century, chocolate houses were popular in European cities, where people would gather to drink chocolate.

In 1826, a Dutch inventor created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. Then, in 1847, a British company made the first solid chocolate bar by combining cocoa butter with sugar and chocolate liquor. Later, a Swiss company added milk to the recipe, creating milk chocolate.

In the UK, the chocolate market was once dominated by French companies, but then Cadbury introduced their famous Dairy Milk bar in 1905. The company's clever marketing campaign associated the bar with the health benefits of milk from the English countryside, making it a popular choice.

Today, chocolate is still a big business, but manufacturers are looking for new ways to attract customers. They're doing this by creating new products, like chocolate ice cream and chocolate drinks. At the same time, cacao farmers are still feeling the effects of a price crash in the 1980s, which forced many small-scale farmers out of business.<|eot_id|>

Losing your luggage when you travel can be very frustrating. Imagine arriving at the airport and finding out that your bag is not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline finds your luggage. This can be especially difficult if you're in a different climate or far from home. Airlines don't usually tell us how often they lose luggage, but it's a common problem. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes. They can't guarantee that your luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have a layover.

Airlines have a system to handle baggage. They ask passengers to check in early so that their bags can be loaded onto the plane. They also have minimum connecting times, which are the shortest time it takes to transfer between flights. These times are a bit longer than usual to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, the system works well, but delays and security checks can cause problems. Human error or accidents can also happen.

Large airports, called hubs, can be particularly challenging because they handle a lot of bags. For example, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers last year, and many of them were transferring flights. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. Some airports, like Miami, are known for luggage getting lost when passengers make quick connections.

To reduce the risk of losing your luggage, try to take direct flights whenever possible. Check in early and make sure your luggage is labeled correctly with your home and holiday addresses, as well as the flight numbers. If you do have to change planes, try to fly with the same airline and allow extra time for connections. If your luggage still goes missing, go to the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report before leaving the airport.

We spent six hours there and were happy to have places to rest our feet. The park's landscaping is beautiful and the staff are friendly and helpful.

Adventure World was a lot of fun. The children loved the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line, which was a bit scary for them. They also enjoyed Running River, where you think you'll get wet but don't. There's a special area for younger children called Toy Land. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't boring. It's also very clean and the staff are great.

The Great Park is perfect for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. We all enjoyed Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then gets exciting. We waited for 30 minutes for Lightning River, but it was over before we knew it! The park closes at 5 pm, so we didn't have as much time as we would have liked.

Fantasy World has a lot to offer. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is a must-try. The older children went on several rides, but some were too scary for the younger ones. The staff were friendly, but not all of them were welcoming. We needed a full day to enjoy the park, and we wouldn't have wanted to leave early."

These schools are different from regular schools because they have a smaller number of students, with a high teacher-to-student ratio. Children at these schools spend most of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, and theory classes. They also have time to practice in private rooms with a teacher.

The schools are independent and charge fees, which can be high (around £12,000-17,000 per year for boarders). However, each school tries to help parents find ways to pay the fees. Some parents might not want their children to go to boarding school, especially at a young age. The directors of the music schools think that it's important to make sure children are well-rounded and balanced, but they also know that putting too much pressure on young children can be stressful.

Some people think that taking children out of their normal school at a young age can cause them to lose their natural talent or feel too much pressure to succeed. However, the music schools keep a close eye on each child's progress and offer help if needed. Many former students feel that they benefited from the music schools, but some think that the academic program could be better.

People love dolphins because they are intelligent, emotional, and seem free in the wild. We see them in movies and TV shows, but the reality is different. According to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, the situation is critical. Dolphins are in trouble due to pollution and overfishing.

There are 40 different kinds of dolphins, but some populations are declining. In the North Sea, the harbour porpoise population has decreased by up to 89,000. You might expect these popular animals to be protected, but they are not. This could be one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

Dolphins in northern Europe include striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoises. Some dolphins live far out at sea, while others are found near European coasts. The bottlenose dolphins were once common in British rivers and coastal areas, but now they are mostly found in Scotland and Wales. The few remaining dolphins are showing signs of stress.

It's difficult to understand why dolphin numbers are declining, but overfishing and pollution are likely causes. Overfishing reduces the fish supply, making it hard for dolphins to find food. Dolphins also get caught in fishing nets, which can be invisible to them. Many dolphins have been found dead on beaches with injuries from nets.

Dolphins can store pollutants in their bodies, including pesticides, which can be passed on to their babies through their milk. There is already a recorded case of a baby dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Noise pollution from ships and other human activities can also disturb dolphins, which may affect their behavior in ways we don't yet understand.

* Increase your muscle power and maintain good posture
* Prevent injuries caused by muscle imbalances
* Improve specific areas of your body, such as your thighs, stomach, and upper arms
* Keep your heart and lungs healthy and improve blood circulation

You may have heard these reasons before, but there are some new benefits to consider. Exercise can also help:

* Ease depression and tiredness
* Regulate your sleep patterns
* Control stress
* Relieve certain medical conditions

There are many types of exercise you can do, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weightlifting. Remember to start slowly and carefully to avoid injury. If you're unsure, consult with your doctor about what's best for you.

Good posture is also important. If you tend to slouch, try imagining a helium balloon attached to the top of your head, lifting you up. This can help you lift your chest and lengthen your abdomen, making your body look slimmer.

Stretching exercises can improve your flexibility and make it easier to move. They can also help you maintain good posture and prevent injuries. Try to stretch four or five times a week to see the benefits.

The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching exercises, a fun and energetic workout, and a cool-down period.<|eot_id|>

Body language also plays a big role in an interview. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 55% of our message comes from our facial expressions. Make sure your words and body language match. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate or too eager for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, got a job offer on the spot, but reacted too enthusiastically and got a lower salary than she wanted.

Finally, it's a good idea to prepare for an interview by learning about the company. This will show your interest and give a positive impression. Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and speaking in short, clear sentences.

C Dieter (yacht racer) When we're on a boat together, we have a great time. We're a traditional group and always celebrate a win in style. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and the arguments about sugar and health are not convincing when compared to the attractive ads.

Many parents are worried about what they feed their children and have their own ideas about what is healthy. However, these ideas are not always accurate. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that parents and children should have a dialogue about food, but it's difficult when children are constantly exposed to advertising.

Some parents feel stressed when deciding which demands to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to explain to her son about advertisements, and now he is critical of them. They have fewer arguments about what to buy because he doesn't ask for things she doesn't want.

Parents also admit that they are inconsistent and sometimes hypocritical in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of two, says that he and his wife refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're bad for him, but they buy treats for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent and sometimes says yes to his children's requests when he's feeling generous.

Supermarkets could make shopping easier for parents by moving sweets away from the checkout area or providing play areas for children. This would make parents more likely to shop there, even if they spend less because their children are not with them.

Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

Ice Skating: A Fun and Challenging Activity

Ice skating has a long history, dating back thousands of years. The first skates were made from animal bones. In Scandinavia, skating was an important skill for the upper classes. In the early 20th century, skating was a stylish and exclusive activity. However, the 1924 Winter Olympics changed everything when 11-year-old Sonja Henie introduced a more athletic approach to skating. Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, requiring both skill and physical fitness.

To start, it's essential to learn how to balance and control your movements. Keep your body weight centered by bending your knees and keeping your legs slightly bent. Relaxation is also crucial, as it will help you to avoid injuries. To begin, stand with your heels almost touching and your feet turned outwards. Move your back foot forward while making a small movement with your other foot.

As you gain experience, you can increase the length of your movements. It's also important to learn how to fall safely. Even experienced skaters fall sometimes, but by being relaxed, you can minimize the impact. To get up, kneel down and then stand up.

There are different styles of ice skating, such as figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. However, it's recommended to start with figure skating and then move on to freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance and lessons, so you can learn the basics quickly.

To improve your skating, practice regularly and focus on exercises that loosen up your legs, back, and shoulders. It's also important to warm up before and after skating to avoid stiffness. Ice skating can improve your balance, coordination, relaxation, and overall fitness. It's a great activity to combine with swimming or jogging for a well-rounded fitness program.<|eot_id|>

Chris Greener is the tallest man in Britain, standing at 228 cm. He told his careers teacher at school that he wanted to join the navy when he left school. The teacher asked him what he wanted to be, and Chris replied, "The flagpole on a ship." Chris is tall because, on average, people in Europe are getting taller every decade. This is because of better nutrition and health.

For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, and meat. They were healthy and strong. However, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming and grew crops like wheat, rice, and maize. This change had a negative impact on human health and physique. People became shorter and weaker because they were eating a diet that was not as nutritious.

In the past, scientists found that when people started eating corn, they became sickly and underweight. This was because corn is high in carbohydrates and low in nutrients. Even in wealthy countries, people were not getting enough nutrients until recently.

Now, people in some countries like the US, Holland, and Japan are eating a more varied diet again, and their average height is increasing. The average height in these countries is around 177-180 cm. However, there are concerns that people may not be able to grow forever. Scientists think that there may be a limit to how tall humans can grow.

Some scientists believe that humans may have been taller in the past, during the last ice age. They think that as the climate warms up, humans may actually get smaller again. This means that the growth of humans could be offset by global warming.

Parents are worried about what their children eat and have their own ideas about what is healthy. However, these ideas might not be correct. It's good that parents and children discuss what they eat, but if the only information children get is from TV ads, they might only see one side of the story. 

Some parents feel stressed when deciding what to buy and what not to buy. They might feel unhappy about how they manage their children's requests. One mother said she talks to her son about different products and labels, and he is critical of ads. They have fewer arguments now because he doesn't ask for things she won't buy. 

Parents admit they are not consistent in their responses to their children's requests. They might say no to sweets because they are bad for their children, but then buy chocolate and cream for themselves. It's hard to be consistent and make decisions.

"Climbing has changed a lot over the years. In the past, climbers would go to mountains to practice. Now, you can climb almost anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd is holding its breath as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down from his fingers on the climbing wall at the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham. The National Indoor Arena is usually known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but it's also hosting the climbing championships. This is because of new technology that makes it possible.

In the past, climbers would practice on cliffs, but this wasn't always possible. They would either have to tolerate the cold weather or go for a walk instead. As the sport developed, it was important for top climbers to stay fit. So, they started using brick edges and stone buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong and not get bored.

Many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing. These walls had special edges that climbers could hold onto. The idea of setting natural rock in a block of concrete was first developed by a physical education teacher named Don Robinson. He built a climbing wall in his department at Leeds University in the 1960s.

However, these early walls had some problems. They could only be built straight up and down, whereas cliffs have overhangs and angled rock. Climbers would eventually get bored with the same old walls. In the 1980s, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a material that could be molded into shapes like those found on cliffs. This could be attached to any wall and then removed when climbers got bored. French manufacturers also started experimenting with panels on steel frames. This made it possible to create overhanging walls without major construction work. The system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers an endless supply of new holds."<|eot_id|>

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to make a career as an actor, they will probably say it's a risky choice. And they're right - there are more actors than there are jobs. The truth is, becoming an actor is a personal decision, and only you can take responsibility for your own success.

There's no easy way to become an actor. There are no exams to pass or guarantees of success. It's all about luck and talent. But there is a demand for new faces and new talent, and there's always the possibility of exciting opportunities and rewards.

So, what is talent? I think it's a combination of natural ability and imagination. It's hard to measure, but it's about being brave and believing in yourself and your work.

Why do people want to act? It's often hard to explain, but for many, it's the thrill of connecting with an audience. That moment of connection is what drives actors to keep acting, whether it's on stage or screen.

When asked how they've succeeded in their careers, actors often shrug and say they don't really know. They know some things about themselves and their craft, but they take nothing for granted. They know that their success can be short-lived, and disappointment is always a risk.

Actors often don't talk about their chances of getting a part because they know that rejection is a possibility. They have to find ways to cope with the stress and uncertainty of competing for roles. Nobody likes being rejected, and it's a risk that comes with the job from the very beginning.

Ultimately, becoming an actor is about being willing to take risks and care enough to make it happen. If you don't care, nobody else will either.<|eot_id|>

Chris Greener is the tallest man in Britain, standing at 228 cm. This is because the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. Many people are now taller than before because they are eating better. This is similar to how our ancestors used to live 40,000 years ago. They ate a variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and animals. This diet kept them healthy and strong.

However, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming, and this changed everything. They grew crops like wheat, rice, and maize, which became the main source of food. This diet was not as good for people's health and made them shorter and weaker. In one study, scientists found that people who started eating corn became sickly and underweight.

It's only recently that people have started eating a more varied diet again, and this is why the average height of people in some countries is increasing. In the US, the average height is 179 cm, in Holland it's 180 cm, and in Japan it's 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it also means that beds, planes, and trains need to be designed for taller people.

But scientists think that there may be a limit to how tall people can grow. Some say it could be as much as 193 cm, but others think we may actually be getting smaller because of climate change. During the last ice age, people were taller and rounder because they needed to keep warm. Now that the climate is warming up, people may become smaller and thinner again. So, the growth of humans could be stopped by global warming.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are running a successful business based on a childhood game. They are sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, playing the game of pichenotte with a wooden board and round plastic pieces. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, introduced the game to their family from Quebec, Canada, where it was popular. The family played the game every weekend and holiday, and visitors were often fascinated by it.

Years ago, Dave decided to make a new pichenotte board because the old one was damaged. People who saw it were interested, and soon friends and relatives wanted to buy one. The brothers took one of the boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe and it became very popular. People started to ask about the game's origins, and Dave researched it. He found that the game is similar to a game called carroms from India, which was adapted into a game called squails in Britain and brought to Canada by British immigrants. In Quebec, the game became known as pichenotte.

Pichenotte is a game of skill that can be played by two to four people. Players use small pieces called pucks and try to flick them across a board with their fingers. The goal is to get the pucks into holes or around the board. The game is usually played for two minutes and is very popular. The Lagasse brothers started making more boards and selling them at markets and craft fairs. People loved the game, and soon they were selling more than 450 boards. They even created a championship and a trophy.

The brothers decided to turn their hobby into a full-time business and set up a workshop in their garage. They make each board by hand, using birchwood and mahogany, and they are very durable. The brothers sell the boards on their website for $595 each. Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are happy to be making a living from the game they love.<|eot_id|>

A boat took me across, and I saw a sign pointing to a jungle. I walked up the path, which was steep and slippery. I met Baba, who ran a tented kitchen and huts. I stayed there for the night, despite the insects. The next morning, I saw a beautiful view of the mountains. In the afternoon, it rained, and I got wet. I slid down the hill, wondering how butterflies avoided the big drops. I was worried about my car, but it was still there when I got back.

In Kota Bahru, the capital, everyone was friendly and asked me questions. I remember Kelantan for its kindness, not just its kites.

What is money? Money is like a measure, like a gram or a kilometre. But instead of measuring things, you can use it to buy things. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper, which doesn't cost much to make.

A long time ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, farmers would exchange their food for other things they needed. For example, Mr. Green would trade his corn for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a deal between two people who had something the other wanted.

As time went on, most societies created their own special money, so people could trade more easily. These different types of money started to work together, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>
Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

Write a great story and you could win £1,000! Ten other people will win £100. The judges are looking for interesting and original stories. They want to read about things that are new and surprising. 

Here are some tips to help you write a good story:

* Write about things you know. Last year, most people wrote about love, family, and friends.
* Make the ordinary seem interesting by writing about it in a new way.
* Make sure you get the facts right. If you're writing about a place or something technical, make sure you're accurate.
* Start your story with something interesting and end it with a surprise.
* Try to make your characters come alive by using the right words to describe them.
* Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed on one side of the paper. Don't send it by email or fax. You need to include the application form with your story.

Some important rules:

* Your story can't have been published in a magazine or book in the UK or anywhere else in the world.
* You can't have won a prize for a story before.
* If you win, you need to agree to let us publish your story in our magazine.

The closing date is 30 July, and we'll tell the winner within a month.<|eot_id|>

She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas and wrote several important books on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented some tools to help her with her work. Unfortunately, many rulers at that time were afraid of science and people connected to it were in danger. Sadly, Hypatia was attacked and killed in the street in March 415.

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It's a big challenge because of its cold climate. Keith Hewitt, a climber, remembers his first winter climb on Ben Nevis. In February, he and his group went up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's a long climb, about 600 metres. They planned to camp halfway up the mountain for three days. They brought all the necessary equipment, including tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for their boots, because the snow was very hard and slippery.

Even though some of the group were experienced climbers, they took all the necessary safety precautions. The weather forecast was good, but they still felt a bit nervous when they set out. Ben Nevis in winter is always a big challenge.

The track was steep and my legs felt heavy. I had to rest more often because I'm not as fit as the others. They would stop to let me catch up, but then they would start climbing again. I promised myself that next time I would train more before a climb.

After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the route to the top of Ben Nevis. It's very narrow and steep, with a big drop on both sides. We had to be very careful and concentrate as we walked along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. But on our day, there was mist.

Getting back down the mountain can be just as difficult as going up. You need to be able to read a map carefully to avoid taking a wrong turn. I was relieved that we took turns doing this job. When I was finally in my tent, I could relax and say that I really enjoyed the experience. At least I made it to the top!<|eot_id|>

Our new school has five big classrooms, which are much larger than our old school. We also have a nursery, a dining room, and big changing rooms. If we sing in class, it's like being in a concert hall!

You'll also notice that there's a tree on the roof! The builders put it there as a special tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went to see it yesterday, and it's huge! We can see it from miles away. We took pictures and will put them on our website.

Even though we're already using the school, there are still some things to be added. For example, we're putting on a play for parents, but we have to use our old school hall for now. I was so upset that I stood by the side of the road and cried. A kind young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened, and he gave me some money to help me get home. When I told the bus driver, he said I didn't need to pay for the fare. I was relieved and grateful.

When I got home, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owns the bus. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, the Arctic was a popular destination in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice all to themselves. In the late 1980s, people started to think that the cold and dark winter could be a good thing. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to have an exhibition in a special igloo in a small town called Jukkasjarvi, near the frozen Torne River. The igloo, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of guests decided to sleep in the igloo. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience and the idea of an ice hotel was born.

Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world. Every year, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They work on different parts of the hotel, and each part opens to visitors and guests as it is finished. The first part is usually finished in December, and then a new part opens every week until January 7th, when the hotel is complete.

Since the hotel is built outside, using natural materials like snow and ice, the finishing date depends on the weather. In the spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it's very cold outside. Guests can borrow warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves, and it's a good idea to bring your own warm clothes and socks as well.

If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and other things you need on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order them when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle, but it's close to Kiruna airport and train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the hotel.

Tanya trains for two thirds of the day, which includes exercises at the gym, in the pool, and in the ocean. She also uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness. She doesn't run because she doesn't want to hurt her knees, but she finds that fast walking is a good way to stay fit.

When Tanya is preparing for an event, she usually travels to a new place and does 14 dives over a four-week period. She takes a rest day between each dive to avoid getting tired. When she's not training, Tanya makes public appearances to promote sports products and support environmental organizations. She also does research projects and makes films.

Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, where she loved swimming and exploring the ocean. She says that her life today is like living her childhood dreams. Because she's well-known, people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. Tanya plans to continue breaking her own records and says she won't retire from free-diving for many years to come.

The route, called the Iditarod Trail, took about three weeks to complete. Teams of dogs and their drivers would stop at 'roadhouses' along the way to rest and eat.

The trail was used for many years, but eventually, airplanes replaced dog sleds as the main way to transport goods. However, in 1925, a serious disease called diphtheria broke out in Nome. The only medicine that could cure the disease was in Anchorage, but it was too far away. Since airplanes couldn't fly in the cold weather, dog sleds were used to transport the medicine instead. Twenty teams of dogs and their drivers traveled over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail, and delivered the medicine in just six days.

Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian, led the first part of the journey with his dog Togo. Togo was an excellent guide and helped them navigate through the snowy terrain. The rest of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had experience driving dog sleds. His lead dog, Saito, was very skilled. At one point, one of the dogs, Balto, refused to continue and saved the team from falling into icy water. Thanks to Balto, the medicine was delivered, and the diphtheria outbreak was stopped.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as the famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth.'<|eot_id|>

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights**

Welcome to our website! Here's what you need to know before booking a flight.

We take tourists on a special flight over Antarctica from Sydney, Australia, in a big plane (Boeing 747) during the short Antarctic summer. The flight is about 12 hours long. We usually see sea ice and icebergs after four hours, and then spend four hours flying over Antarctica. The rest of the time is spent flying back home. During the flight, experts who have lived on Antarctic research stations will talk to us about the environment and history, and answer our questions.

You'll have two boarding passes. At the halfway point, you'll move to the seat shown on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half the flight and a seat at the end of the row for the other half.

While we're over Antarctica, we encourage you to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in a special pattern to make sure everyone can see the amazing sights from both sides of the plane.

What if the weather is bad? We have 17 different flight plans, and the captain chooses the best one based on the weather forecast. Will I see penguins and other wildlife? Unfortunately, most Antarctic animals live at sea level, so we can't see them in detail from the plane. We don't land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you'd need to join a boat tour.

Can I take photos? Yes, you can bring your camera! We even have some fun photo opportunities on the plane where you can try on Antarctic cold-weather clothes.

* Simplified vocabulary and sentence structure
* Removed technical terms and jargon
* Added transitional phrases to connect ideas
* Reduced the amount of information presented at once
* Made the text more concise and easy to follow<|eot_id|>

"Winter driving can be dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen and accidents can happen quickly. Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and hidden ice can cause your car to slide off the road. The car coming towards you might also slide across the road. To drive safely on icy roads, follow these two important rules.

First, drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car difficult to control. Imagine you're driving with a cup of hot coffee next to you - drive carefully so you don't spill it.

Second, be prepared for what might happen. On icy roads, you need to look further ahead than usual. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. When the road is wet, snowy, or icy, leave more space between you and the car in front of you. Try to stay in control of your car at all times, and you'll be less likely to get into trouble."

Here is the simplified text for a B2 learner:

Craigie Aitchison was a Scottish painter. He went to London to study law, but ended up at art school instead. He found the traditional drawing classes hard, but kept painting. When he was in his late 20s, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. He became interested in the work of early Italian artists and was inspired by the green and brown landscapes and the clear light of Italy.

Aitchison loved to paint by layering colours from light to dark. He never knew exactly what the final result would be, and he says it's a secret because he doesn't know himself. He doesn't start with a plan, like painting a yellow base coat and then adding more colours. Instead, he simply notices what colours work well together.

Aitchison never does sketches before starting a painting. He thinks that if he does, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he makes many changes to his paintings before they're complete. That's why he prefers to work with models who don't want to see their pictures while he's painting. If they get worried and want to look at the painting, he can't concentrate.

Aitchison moved to London many years ago and doesn't feel part of the Scottish art scene. He doesn't follow any specific style or tradition, but paints in his own way. Despite this, his work has influenced many young British painters.<|eot_id|>
